articles.headline: Iraqi Contracts With Iran and China Concern U.S.
articles.snippet: American officials fear that commercial investments in Iraqi power plants could mask military activities by Iran.
articles.abstract: American officials fear that commercial investments in Iraqi power plants could mask military activities by Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 17 — Iraq has agreed to award $1.1 billion in contracts to Iranian and Chinese companies to build a pair of enormous power plants, the Iraqi electricity minister said Tuesday. Word of the project prompted serious concerns among American military officials, who fear that Iranian commercial investments can mask military activities at a time of heightened tension with Iran.

articles.headline: Plan Would Ease Limits on Media Owners
articles.snippet: An F.C.C. proposal to relax decades-old rules would be a big victory for some executives of media conglomerates.
articles.abstract: An F.C.C. proposal to relax decades-old rules would be a big victory for some executives of media conglomerates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 — The head of the Federal Communications Commission has circulated an ambitious plan to relax the decades-old media ownership rules, including repealing a rule that forbids a company to own both a newspaper and a television or radio station in the same city.

articles.headline: Networks Start to Offer TV on the Web
articles.snippet: The TV networks have begun to put programs on the Web. The selections are crisp, clear, legal and free. But there aren’t many choices, and they don’t stay on the Web long enough.
articles.abstract: The TV networks have begun to put programs on the Web. The selections are crisp, clear, legal and free. But there aren’t many choices, and they don’t stay on the Web long enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: Music and TV were lazily paddling their canoes down Prosperity Creek when Music suddenly heard a deafening roar ahead. “Help! What’s happening?” cried Music  but it was too late. The canoe tumbled over the Internet Falls, knocking Music upside-down into the churning vortex.

articles.headline: A Headache for Small Drug Makers
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. has begun to crack down on the thousands of drugs, often made by small companies, that have never had to go through the agency’s stringent approval process.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. has begun to crack down on the thousands of drugs, often made by small companies, that have never had to go through the agency’s stringent approval process.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Larry Blansett was producing a wide array of prescription cough syrups, antihistamine tablets and pain killers at the company he co-founded, UAD Laboratories. But the Food and Drug Administration was not keeping a close watch.

articles.headline: Countrywide Chief Is Said to Face S.E.C. Inquiry
articles.snippet: Angelo R. Mozilo has been criticized by Countrywide shareholders who question the timing of his stock sales in the months before the company’s shares plummeted as the mortgage crisis deepened.
articles.abstract: Angelo R. Mozilo has been criticized by Countrywide shareholders who question the timing of his stock sales in the months before the company’s shares plummeted as the mortgage crisis deepened.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an informal investigation into the stock sales of the chief executive of Countrywide Financial, a person briefed on the matter said last night, the latest problem to hit the struggling mortgage lender.

articles.headline: Turkey Resolves to Give Go-Ahead for Raids in Iraq
articles.snippet: Turkey, a member of NATO, made it clear that it would not immediately carry out the resolution.
articles.abstract: Turkey, a member of NATO, made it clear that it would not immediately carry out the resolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL, Oct. 17 — Turkey’s Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to authorize sending troops into northern Iraq to confront Kurdish rebels in hide-outs there, sending an angry message to the Baghdad government and its Washington sponsor. But Turkey, a member of NATO, made it clear that it would not immediately carry out the resolution.
articles.byline: By Sebnem Arsu and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Seeing Sugar’s Future in Fuel
articles.snippet: After seeing Midwestern farmers improve their lot by selling corn to ethanol distilleries, sugar cane and sugar beet growers want their own ethanol deal, paid for by U.S. taxpayers.
articles.abstract: After seeing Midwestern farmers improve their lot by selling corn to ethanol distilleries, sugar cane and sugar beet growers want their own ethanol deal, paid for by U.S. taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOREAUVILLE, La. — Todd Landry, a farmer who conjures big stands of sugar cane from the muddy fields of southern Louisiana, has been struggling lately against droughts and freezes and hurricanes. Come January he will confront another peril: expanded sugar imports from Mexico.

articles.headline: Accused Law Firm Continues Giving to Democrats
articles.snippet: Milberg Weiss, which was indicted on charges of fraud and bribery, still has a political partnership with Democrats.
articles.abstract: Milberg Weiss, which was indicted on charges of fraud and bribery, still has a political partnership with Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, as it became Exhibit A for critics of shareholders’ class action lawsuits, the law firm of Milberg Weiss often enjoyed the support of Democrats who called the suits an invaluable weapon in the universal conflict between big business and the little guy.

articles.headline: Big Holder Sells Stake in Times Co.
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley has sold its 7.2 percent stake in The New York Times Company, bringing an end to its campaign to change the media company’s dual-class share structure.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley has sold its 7.2 percent stake in The New York Times Company, bringing an end to its campaign to change the media company’s dual-class share structure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley has sold its 7.2 percent stake in The New York Times Company, people close to the matter said yesterday, bringing an end to a bitter fight between one of the bank’s asset managers and the company.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Geraldine Fabrikant
